They are saying that skillshot **indicators** are different, not the actual skillshot VFX. If you're using quickcast for all abilities there's no difference at all, except those range indicators for high range abilities like Xerath or Jhin ult.
Speaking about those, the Rioter you're quoting made a mistake. They meant to say that the range shown for Jhin is a little bit **smaller**, than for the enemy team. When somebody is just on the line of his ult (from his perspective), he can still hit them and feel good about barely hitting a shot at maximum distance.
On the receiving end, the area is slightly **larger**. If you walk across the outer line people often think they're safe, even though their entire hitbox might not be over the indicated line yet. By making the area slightly larger visually, those moments where you think you're safe but actually aren't are reduced significantly.
This discrepancy leads to less frustration for both sides involved.

And also, this has been known for quite some time. It's not something new Riot just admitted to yesterday.

What I would give for a full interview with Jatt. 

(for reference; 3 ad might not mean much by itself, and it doesn't. It's not supposed to. What its meant for is to create times when you miss a CS because that minion had 105 HP, took 30 damage, and you only have 74 ad. So you miss the minion (and it immediately dies to an in-flight minion attack landing after your auto) and miss out on 21g. 
That 21g means it takes 10 seconds longer for you to back to get a long sword; 25 or so to get an Amp tome, if the rest of your farming is unaffected. 
That lost time means having lower stats than you would normally - 13 AD on a marksman, or 3AD and 12% aspeed - which means you might miss 2 or 3 more minions because of it, slowing down the rate at which you gain gold. it's more of a mid-game nerf than an early one, in terms of champ v champ combat (very early, you havent lost significant gold and 3 ad will almost never influence the result of trades in lane. Very late, and you bought items already and even if your 'late game' is 20 seconds later than it was before, it's still only 3AD weaker.)
The effectiveness of those 3 ad nerfs changes though when the champion is a sheen user like corki. It does add up in fights too.

I'm quite conflicted by these statements. The first post I agree with and makes sense, it acts slightly as a buffer to give a player a hit when they thought it might be a miss and this is specifically with the caster's indicator only. The second post actually seems like he's saying the exact opposite, where the actual range is slightly between the two shown, and that the caster's indicator is actually longer than the missile length??? 

Also, I disagree with the statement "Enemies who see ground indicators expect to be safe when they're 'almost outside'". If I see a ground indicator I only expect to not be hit if I'm fully outside that indicator. If he had said partly outside I could understand, but almost outside is a ridiculous thing to expect.

The statement is from someone with a technical mind. There is no "partially", nor is there "almost" in programming. Either the character capsule is in, or it's out. Period. No question, no exceptions. Visually, a character can have its feet outside of the line, yet their collision capsule can still be in range (and thus can be hit by Jhin's ult projectile). THAT is what he's referring to. "Almost outside" would mean they player THINKS they are outside, yet the collision capsule is still inside.

If the range indicator is slightly smaller for Jhin and his allies, and slightly larger for the enemy team (which is the case -- the screenshotted posts are typos, you can test it with friends in a custom game to validate), it inherently means that if their FEET are outside of the indicator, the character capsule will not be hit. Whereas if the indicator was exactly the same for everyone, moving to what appears to be outside of the indicator line may not actually be outside of it. Collision capsules are very often wider than the span of feet, and a good deal (2-3 times) larger in regards to forward/backward from the feet. When you account for armor and other visuals (think Garen) the capsule can be a great deal larger than where the feet are.

OP does not understand the first thing about game mechanics. This is 100% industry standard, exists in every game, and is nothing new. It's a GOOD thing to do. It provides a small but crucial visual buffer to allow someone to visually KNOW where they need to stand to not get hit.
